questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: (FMGE JAN 2025) pH: 7.50 PaCO₂: 48 mmHg HCO₃: 33 mmol/L What is the most likely acid-base disturbance in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic alkalosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient has metabolic alkalosis due to:
  • • Elevated pH (> 7.45), indicating alkalemia. Elevated HCO₃ (> 26 mEq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis. Clinical history of vomiting, which leads to the loss of chloride (via gastric acid - Hcl), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting suggests that the patient may suffer from bulimia nervosa , a psychiatric illness. Compensatory increase in PaCO₂ (normal: 35-45 mmHg), as per expected compensation using the Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis : Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16 In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2) So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • Elevated pH (> 7.45), indicating alkalemia.
  • • pH
  • • Elevated HCO₃ (> 26 mEq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis.
  • • HCO₃
  • • Clinical history of vomiting, which leads to the loss of chloride (via gastric acid - Hcl), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.
  • • Binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting suggests that the patient may suffer from bulimia nervosa , a psychiatric illness.
  • • bulimia nervosa
  • • Compensatory increase in PaCO₂ (normal: 35-45 mmHg), as per expected compensation using the Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis : Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16 In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2) So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • PaCO₂
  • • Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis
  • • Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16 In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2) So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16
  • • 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20
  • • 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16
  • • In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2) So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg.
  • • 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2)
  • • So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg.
  • • The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Metabolic acidosis : Incorrect, as this would present with low pH (<7.4) and low HCO₃ (<24)
  • • Option A. Metabolic acidosis
  • • low pH
  • • low HCO₃ (<24)
  • • Option C. Respiratory acidosis : Incorrect, as the patient’s pH is 7.5 (alkalotic) and in acidosis pH would generally be low (< 7.4)
  • • Option C. Respiratory acidosis
  • • Option D. Respiratory alkalosis : Incorrect, as this would present with low PaCO₂ (< 40) and high pH (>7.4)
  • • Option D. Respiratory alkalosis
  • • low PaCO₂

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic vomiting results in loss of chloride (in the vomitus), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic Alkalosis is usually characterized by elevated pH and HCO₃ , with appropriate respiratory compensation ( elevated PaCO₂ - due to hypoventilation ).
  • ➤ Chronic vomiting
  • ➤ elevated pH and HCO₃
  • ➤ elevated PaCO₂ - due to hypoventilation

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats and the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. Always consider sarcoidosis first in such clinical scenarios.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 deficiency, often due to pernicious anemia, is characterized by macrocytic anemia, hypersegmented neutrophils, and atrophic gastritis. This condition involves an autoimmune mechanism that impairs the production and function of intrinsic factor, essential for vitamin B12 absorption.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child complains of mild painful swelling over the scalp for 3 months as shown in the image below. He also has a pet dog at his home. What is the diagnosis of the given condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Kerion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kerion is a boggy, tender scalp swelling associated with hair loss and potentially linked to animal exposure, indicative of a f ungal infection rather than a bacterial cause like furuncle or folliculitis, or a benign lesion such as an epidermoid cyst.
  • ➤ Kerion
  • ➤ boggy,
  • ➤ scalp swelling
  • ➤ hair loss
  • ➤ ungal

References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11
  • ↳ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption. Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.
  • ➤ Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • ➤ Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lecithin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RDS is a common condition in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production, particularly the deficiency of lecithin. The educational objective is to understand the etiology of RDS and its association with surfactant components, specifically lecithin. This knowledge is crucial for healthcare professionals involved in the care of neonates, as RDS can have serious respiratory consequences in premature infants and requires appropriate management and support.

questions.text: In a case where a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy (MDT) experiences a deterioration of existing lesions and nerve complications, what course of action would you consider taking next? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of nerve complications in a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy for conditions like leprosy , the appropriate course of action is to continue the anti-microbial therapy and start systemic steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction causing nerve damage.
  • ➤ nerve complications
  • ➤ multi-drug therapy
  • ➤ leprosy
  • ➤ continue the anti-microbial therapy
  • ➤ systemic steroids
  • ➤ inflammatory

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.5, 28.12, 28.16
  • ↳ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.5, 28.12, 28.16

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant female is advised to take folic acid supplements. Folic acid is given in pregnancy to prevent which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neural tube defects

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Folic acid supplementation in pregnancy is essential to prevent neural tube defects, with the standard recommended dose being 400 micrograms per day, increased to 4000 micrograms for those at higher risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about a patient who presented in the OPD with a swelling as shown in the image? The swelling is reducible. (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Reduce the swelling and do the observation

options.label: C
options.text: Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

questions.correct_answer: C. Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For reducible hernias, the appropriate treatment is surgical repair with mesh reinforcement to prevent recurrence and avoid complications. Observation alone is not sufficient, and procedures such as incision and drainage are not applicable.

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NPH is characterized by Dementia, Apraxia/Magnetic gait with urinary incontinence due to frontal lobe dysfunction

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Dementia/Chap 434

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the upper GI endoscopy image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Esophageal varices

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dilated column of veins in esophagus represent varices.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent a bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.correct_answer: D. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair. Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.
  • ➤ Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair.
  • ➤ Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV 60fL, and RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) HbA2 levels

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary lymphoid organ? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ where T cells mature, playing a crucial role in the development of the immune system.
  • ➤ Spleen, lymph node and tonsils are considered as secondary lymphoid organs
  • ➤ Bone marrow has been considered as an example of both a primary as well as a secondary lymphoid organ.

questions.text: IPC Section 314 deals with? ( NEET PG 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Abortion leading to death of mother

options.label: D
options.text: Preventing the child from being born alive

questions.correct_answer: C. Abortion leading to death of mother
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Abortion leading to death of mother

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IPC Section 314 deals specifically with the death of the mother during a criminal abortion.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the detection of monkeypox? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most effective and standard method for the detection of monkeypox is PCR, which detects the DNA of the orthopoxvirus in clinical specimens.

questions.text: Which influenza virus was responsible for the 2009 pandemic? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) H1N1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Influenza Pandemics
  • ➤ Influenza Pandemics
  • ➤ SWINE FLU, H1N1 → 2009, Mexico
  • ➤ BIRD FLU, H7N9 → 2013, China
  • ➤ BIRD FLU, H5N1 → 1997, Hong Kong
  • ➤ BIRD FLU, H10N3 → 2021, China

questions.text: How does this graft get nutrition on day 3? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Inosculation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ On day 3, a skin graft receives nutrition primarily through inosculation, where early vascular connections form between the graft and the recipient bed, allowing for initial blood supply to the graft.

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Septate hymen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given image is suggestive of the septate hymen. The hymen is the membranous vestige of the junction between the sino-vaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus, which perforates during fetal life to establish a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum. Defective perforation of this structure may result in the following variants of hymen: Imperforate hymen : Without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty) Micro-perforate hymen : Tiny opening Annular hymen : Oval central opening Septate hymen : Two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (May have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon) Naviculate hymen : Boat-like opening
  • • The given image is suggestive of the septate hymen.
  • • The hymen is the membranous vestige of the junction between the sino-vaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus, which perforates during fetal life to establish a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum.
  • • Defective perforation of this structure may result in the following variants of hymen: Imperforate hymen : Without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty) Micro-perforate hymen : Tiny opening Annular hymen : Oval central opening Septate hymen : Two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (May have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon) Naviculate hymen : Boat-like opening
  • • Imperforate hymen : Without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty) Micro-perforate hymen : Tiny opening Annular hymen : Oval central opening Septate hymen : Two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (May have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon) Naviculate hymen : Boat-like opening
  • • Imperforate hymen : Without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty)
  • • Imperforate hymen
  • • Micro-perforate hymen : Tiny opening
  • • Micro-perforate hymen
  • • Annular hymen : Oval central opening
  • • Annular hymen
  • • Septate hymen : Two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (May have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon)
  • • Septate hymen
  • • Naviculate hymen : Boat-like opening
  • • Naviculate hymen
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Imperforate hymen : An imperforate hymen has no opening at all and often presents as cryptomenorrhea (accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen) at puberty.
  • • Option A. Imperforate hymen
  • • Option B. Semilunar hymen : A semilunar hymen has a crescent-shaped opening and is not depicted in the image.
  • • Option B. Semilunar hymen
  • • Option D. Annular hymen : An annular hymen has an oval central opening and does not match the septate appearance in the image.
  • • Option D. Annular hymen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A septate hymen is characterized by two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue, which may lead to difficulties with intercourse or tampon use.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 18, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 18, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. Mark the correct biochemical changes which will be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.correct_answer: C. Increased urate and lactate levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased urate and lactate levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Following delivery at a PHC, a patient was referred with the following image. On examination, there is a tear extending to the rectum. Identify the type of tear. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 4th degree tear involves disruption of the anal sphincters and rectal mucosa, making it the most severe form of perineal tear during childbirth.

questions.text: In a given population, total births were 4050 including 50 stillbirths in a given year. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life, and an additional 150 die within 8-28 days of life. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in the population? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 50

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births.

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause? ( NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Viper

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Viper bites are characterized by profuse bleeding, pain, redness, and blister formation due to their vasculotoxic venom.

questions.text: In Presence of ADH, Maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid will be in which of the following site of nephron? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Medullary CD

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ADH increases water permeability in the collecting ducts by inserting aquaporin channels. When ADH is present, as we move from the cortex towards the deep medulla, osmolarity keeps increasing. Though ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum change in osmolarity occurs in the medullary region due to the countercurrent multiplication system maintaining high osmolarity in the medullary interstitium.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. PCT: Incorrect because PCT mainly handles obligatory water reabsorption (60-70%) through osmosis, not regulated by ADH.
  • • Option A. PCT: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Cortical CD: Incorrect because although ADH acts here, the osmotic gradient in the cortex is much lower than in the medulla.
  • • Option B. Cortical CD: Incorrect
  • • Option C. DCT: Incorrect because DCT has minimal water reabsorption (1-3%) without ADH and is not a major site for ADH action.
  • • Option C. DCT: Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid is achieved in the medullary collecting duct due to the high osmotic gradient maintained by the countercurrent multiplication system in the medulla.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine evaluation. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 24 weeks. Ultrasonography revealed decreased amniotic fluid. Which of the following conditions would have led to this presentation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early onset oligohydramnios can be caused by renal anomalies, with bilateral renal agenesis being a primary condition leading to reduced amniotic fluid levels.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 670, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 670, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has activity against both HBV and HIV? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tenofovir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drugs effective against both HIV and HBV coinfection: Lamivudine, Emtricitabine and Tenofovir
  • ➤ Drugs effective against both HIV and HBV coinfection: Lamivudine, Emtricitabine and Tenofovir

questions.text: A 1-week-old child was presented with early cataract. He also has refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis. This can be caused due to the deficiency of which enzyme? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase and presents with early cataracts, feeding difficulties, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis in newborns.

questions.text: In methanol poisoning, which of these is increased in the blood? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.correct_answer: D. Formic acid and lactic acid
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In methanol poisoning, formic acid and lactic acid levels increase due to disrupted cellular respiration and anaerobic metabolism.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What can be done to prevent future thrombotic events? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Oral warfarin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with atrial fibrillation associated with mitral stenosis, oral warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant to prevent thromboembolic events.

questions.text: This condition is treated by supplementation of which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nicotinamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is treated with niacin or nicotinamide supplementation

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented with chest pain. In an angiogram, her left circumflex artery was found to be stenosed, and a stent was inserted. Her current medications include ASA 75mg OD, atenolol 50mg BID, lovastatin, and lisinopril. What should be done in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Add P2Y12 receptor inhibitor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ After stent placement, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor) is essential to prevent stent thrombosis and ensure optimal patient outcomes.

questions.text: Type of tympanoplasty shown in image Below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Type 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows Type 4 tympanoplasty (Wullstein classification) where:
  • • The graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate All ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes suprastructure) are absent Only the footplate remains Also called cavum minor tympanoplasty
  • • The graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate
  • • All ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes suprastructure) are absent
  • • Only the footplate remains
  • • Also called cavum minor tympanoplasty
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Type 1
  • • Option A. Type 1
  • • Simple myringoplasty with intact ossicular chain Graft placed on handle of malleus All ossicles are present and functional
  • • Simple myringoplasty with intact ossicular chain
  • • Graft placed on handle of malleus
  • • All ossicles are present and functional
  • • Option B. Type 2
  • • Option B. Type 2
  • • Graft placed on incus or remnant of malleus Partial ossicular defect Malleus absent but incus present
  • • Graft placed on incus or remnant of malleus
  • • Partial ossicular defect
  • • Malleus absent but incus present
  • • Option C. Type 3
  • • Option C. Type 3
  • • Also called columella tympanoplasty Graft placed on stapes head Malleus and incus absent but stapes suprastructure present
  • • Also called columella tympanoplasty
  • • Graft placed on stapes head
  • • Malleus and incus absent but stapes suprastructure present

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize Type 4 tympanoplasty as the procedure where the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate when all ossicles are absent except the footplate.
  • ➤ Tympanoplasty –

questions.text: A child present with congenital defect in diaphragm which is located on posterior/postero-lateral aspect of chest. What is your diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bochdalek hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia, characterized by a posterior or posterolateral defect in the diaphragm, usually on the left side . It results from the failure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane to close and leads to pulmonary hypoplasia due to the herniation of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity.
  • ➤ posterior or posterolateral defect
  • ➤ left side
  • ➤ pulmonary hypoplasia

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dL) and LDL 220 mg/dL were found to be raised. What is the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) LDL receptors defect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LDL receptor defects cause familial hypercholesterolemia, characterized by elevated LDL, cholesterol levels, and tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for managing the school health programs? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Primary health center

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are responsible for managing school health programs in India, providing a range of health services to ensure the well-being of school children.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giardia lamblia is a significant cause of diarrheal disease, especially in settings where water or food might be contaminated. Its unique trophozoites are diagnosable through histopathology, emphasizing the need for awareness of water and food hygiene to prevent its transmission. Treatment typically involves specific anti-protozoal medications, and addressing it effectively is crucial in immunocompromised patients to prevent prolonged symptoms and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: A patient with a history of smoking presents with a cough and hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is done and it is shown below. Which of the following findings is least likely to be associated with this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The X-ray findings suggest a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor) , which can invade adjacent structures, causing:
  • • Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor)
  • • Brachial plexopathy (compression of lower brachial plexus) Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) due to sympathetic chain involvement Superior vena cava syndrome due to compression of the superior vena cava
  • • Brachial plexopathy (compression of lower brachial plexus)
  • • Brachial plexopathy
  • • Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) due to sympathetic chain involvement
  • • Horner’s syndrome
  • • sympathetic chain involvement
  • • Superior vena cava syndrome due to compression of the superior vena cava
  • • Superior vena cava syndrome
  • • compression of the superior vena cava
  • • Exophthalmos is more commonly associated with Graves’ disease and is not a feature of Pancoast tumors .
  • • Exophthalmos is more commonly associated with Graves’ disease
  • • not a feature of Pancoast tumors
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Horner syndrome: Incorrect because this is a common finding in Pancoast tumor due to involvement of the sympathetic chain
  • • Option A. Horner syndrome:
  • • Option B. Brachial plexopathy: Incorrect because this is commonly seen due to compression of the lower part of the brachial plexus by the tumor
  • • Option B. Brachial plexopathy:
  • • Option C. Superior vena cava syndrome: Incorrect because SVC syndrome can occur in Pancoast tumors due to compression or invasion of the superior vena cava
  • • Option C. Superior vena cava syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pancoast tumors present with Horner’s syndrome, brachial plexopathy, and superior vena cava syndrome, but exophthalmos is not part of the presentation.

questions.text: Within the framework of Sustainable Development Goal 3, the objective of target 3.1 is to achieve a reduction in the Maternal Mortality Ratio to what specific level (per 1 lakh live births) by the year 2030? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) <70

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SDGs – Targets & Indicators
  • ➤ SDGs – Targets & Indicators
  • ➤ 3.1 - By 2030, MMR < 70
  • ➤ 3.2 - By 2030, NNMR 12 & U5MR 25
  • ➤ 3.3 - By 2030, end epidemics of AIDS, TB, Malaria and NTDs and combat Hepatitis, Water-borne diseases and other CDS.
  • ➤ 3.4 - By 2030, reduce by 1/3 premature mortality from NCDs.
  • ➤ 3.5 - Strengthen the prevention & treatment of substance abuse.
  • ➤ 3.6 - By 2020, halve the global deaths and injuries form RTA.
  • ➤ 3.7 - By 2030, universal access to Sexual & Rep – health care services.
  • ➤ 3.8 - Achieve Universal health coverage.
  • ➤ 3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) presents with an acute attack of migraine. Which of the following medications should not be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sumatriptan, a vasoconstrictor, should not be given to patients with a history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction due to the risk of triggering serious cardiovascular events.

questions.text: Sludder’s neuralgia is due to compression of anterior ethmoidal nerve by septal spur in the region of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Middle turbinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sludder’s neuralgia, or anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, is caused by the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve by a septal spur in the region of the middle turbinate. This condition results in facial pain and headache due to nerve irritation.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her conception chances. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Although cabergoline is often used for prolactinomas due to better tolerability and efficacy, it is not the preferred agent when fertility is desired, especially around the time of conception or planned pregnancy.
  • • According to endocrine guidelines:
  • • According to endocrine guidelines:
  • • Bromocriptine has been safely used for over 30 years in women trying to conceive, with no proven teratogenicity.
  • • Once pregnancy is confirmed, bromocriptine is discontinued to reduce fetal exposure.
  • • Cabergoline, being long-acting with high D₂ receptor affinity, is not recommended during conception planning, due to less extensive safety data in pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cabergoline : Not preferred in women desiring fertility due to longer half-life and limited pregnancy safety data.
  • • Option A. Cabergoline
  • • Option C. Octreotide : A somatostatin analog used for GH-secreting tumors (e.g., acromegaly), not prolactinomas.
  • • Option C. Octreotide
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant : GH receptor antagonist for acromegaly; no role in prolactinoma or fertility.
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In women with microprolactinoma and infertility, bromocriptine is the first-line treatment to restore ovulation and promote safe conception. While cabergoline is effective and often better tolerated, it is not the agent of choice when pregnancy is desired, due to concerns regarding its longer action and limited pregnancy safety data.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone : The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone : The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone
  • • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
  • • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
  • • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
  • • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone : Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone
  • • Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate : Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.
  • • Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate
  • • Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone : Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.
  • ➤ Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules
  • ➤ Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules

questions.text: Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is seen in? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psoriasis is the condition most commonly associated with irregular nail pitting and subungual hyperkeratosis among the options provided.

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery

options.label: B
options.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery- External iliac artery

options.label: C
options.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery

options.label: D
options.text: Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Uterine artery – Ovarian artery – Internal iliac artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The stepwise devascularization approach for managing atonic postpartum hemorrhage includes ligation of the uterine arteries, ovarian arteries, and anterior division of the internal iliac arteries in that specific order.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis should be suspected in young patients with inflammatory back pain that improves with exercise, reduced lung expansion, and extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis. The "bamboo spine" on X-ray is a characteristic finding in advanced cases of AS.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of a child undergoing inguinal hernia repair is shown, with a marked vein in the spermatic cord. What is the likely structure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Testicular vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an open inguinal hernia repair, the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord are the testicular veins. Other veins such as the femoral, obturator, and inferior epigastric veins are located posterior to the inguinal canal and are not seen within the spermatic cord during such procedures.

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise skipped a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Alcohol inhibits which of the following biochemical processes, potentially leading to hypoglycemia: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gluconeogenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcohol consumption inhibits gluconeogenesis by creating a high NADH/NAD+ ratio, which depletes gluconeogenic substrates (pyruvate and oxaloacetate), potentially leading to hypoglycemia, especially when glycogen stores are depleted.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pharyngobasilar Fascia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fig: Relations of tonsil. Tonsil is related laterally to its capsule (1), loose areolar tissue containing paraton- sillar vein (2), superior constrictor muscle (3), styloglossus (4), glossopharyngeal nerve (5), facial artery (6), medial pterygoid muscle (7), angle of mandible (8) and sub- mandibular salivary gland (9), pharyngobasilar fascia (10), buccopharyngeal fascia (11).
  • ➤ Fig:

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Shock

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shock is a critical and life-threatening manifestation of pituitary apoplexy that arises from acute adrenal insufficiency. Immediate recognition and treatment with IV glucocorticoids and fluids are essential to stabilize the patient and prevent further complications. This condition is diagnosed via imaging, typically an MRI, and may require surgical intervention depending on the severity and the presence of neurological symptoms.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Pituitary tumor syndromes/Page no 2897

questions.text: During delivery of a 30y G2P1L1 with previous LSCS, the head was delivered but the shoulders got stuck. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shoulder dystocia is diagnosed when the shoulders fail to deliver within a minute after the head or require specific maneuvers for delivery.
